level_1: Peer review means checking someone else’s code or work.
It helps you spot bugs that the original writer may not see.
Feedback from others helps you grow faster.
Don’t worry about being perfect — everyone improves with review.
Code review is very common in tech companies.
level_2: Peer feedback improves the overall quality of software.
It’s a great way to learn better code practices.
In blogs, developers often talk about how code reviews helped them grow.
You learn not just how to write code, but also how to read and improve it.
Feedback culture creates better teamwork.
level_3: In open-source, code reviews are a must before merging pull requests.
Blogs describe how reviews reveal security or performance issues.
Professional teams review logic, structure, and test coverage.
Reviewing others’ work helps you find mistakes in your own code.
Many blog posts say reviews help build confidence and clarity.
level_4: Experts write about how reviews shape technical leadership.
Senior engineers use reviews to maintain coding standards.
Good feedback is part of scalable and clean development.
Blogs explain how feedback affects decision-making in tech teams.
It’s not just about code — it’s about how teams communicate and grow.

level_1: Read the code fully before saying anything.
Think about what the code is trying to do.
level_2: Ask questions if you don’t understand something.
Be specific when pointing out problems or bugs.
level_3: Don’t just focus on what’s wrong — share why and how to improve it.
Think about readability, naming, and logic clarity.
level_4: Keep reviews focused and goal-oriented.
Senior devs share how structured thinking improves team performance.

level_2: Avoid saying 'wrong' — use 'can be improved'.

level_3: Be clear, not confusing. One short comment is better than a paragraph.
